title: What made the Chevy 302 one of the greatest muscle car engines ever? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q: What made the Chevy 302 one of the greatest muscle car engines ever? While the Chevy 302 was an interesting engine, I don’t think it was one of the greatest muscle car engines ever, and wasn’t really intended to be one. It was developed for SCCA Trans Am racing by combining a 327 4.000″ bore block with a crank with the 283’s 3.000″ stroke in order to be within the sanctioning body’s 5L displacement limit. The 302 had all-forged internals and a solid lifter cam to enable high rpm power, which is where it shone, but as a street engine, it couldn’t compete with big blocks which out-powered and massively out-torqued it since they had far greater displacement and longer stroke cranks. In race trim, they made about 450 hp, but the competing Ford Boss 302, also specially developed for the same race series, was able to make more high rpm hp thanks to its Cleveland type big port, big valve poly-angle heads, though the Chevy tended to do a bit better in the mid-range. The Boss 302 also suffered from the same lack of low end torque that was abundant with muscle car big blocks. Modified Chevy 302s used in drag racing applications needed 4.56:1 or 4.88:1 gears to make up for their lack of low end torque. Hot Rod magazine did a dyno shootout comparing fresh rebuilds of the 1969 Chevy 302 against the 1969 version of the Ford Boss 302 in 2009, and got 356 hp @ 6700 rpm and 333 lb-ft @ 4400 rpm out of the Chevy, and 372 hp @ 6800 rpm and 325 lb-ft @ 4200 rpm from the Ford, which is pretty good for their displacement. However, compare those kinds of numbers against a 1966 Chrysler 426 Street Hemi rebuilt with a 1968–69 cam that produced 494.4 hp @ 5950 rpm and 498.3 lb-ft @ 4500 rpm (521 hp at 5,950 rpm with headers), and you’ll quickly see the difference between street versions of pony car engines configured for SCCA racing and one of the greatest muscle car engines ever.
